metadata.title: Tendinopathy, Posterior Tibialis
description: The tibialis posterior muscle originates at the posterior surface of the interosseous membrane, the posterior surface of the tibia, and the medial surface of the fibula. The posterior tibialis tendon (PTT) travels distally and posteriorly to the medial malleolus. It then splits into 3 components: primary, plantar, and recurrent. The main portion inserts on the navicular bone, the plantar portion inserts onto the base of the 2nd, 3rd, and 4th metatarsals along with the 2nd and 3rd cuneiforms and the cuboid. The recurrent portion inserts at the sustentaculum tali of the calcaneus(8)
The PTT normally functions to(8) –support the medial longitudinal arch (MLA) of the foot –assist in plantar flexion and inversion

Overuse tendon injury should be considered tendinopathy, but NOT tendinitis(15) –Tendinopathy is a clinical syndrome describing overuse tendon injury characterized by pain, swelling, and/or functional limitation –Tendinopathy could be tendinitis (presence of inflammation) or tendinosis (absence of inflammation) –Distinguishing tendinitis from tendinosis is not clinically feasible in most cases –Inflammation is not considered to be part of the pathology in most clinical cases of tendinopathy (anti-inflammatory medications may have no benefit) –Tendinosis is likely more common than tendinitis

ICD-10 codes.M78.6: other enthesopathies of lower limb, excluding foot; anterior tibial syndrome, posterior tibial tendinitis
ICD-10 codes.M76.82: posterior tibial tendinitis (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Pain along the medial aspect of the ankle, hindfoot, and/or MLA
Decreased strength/endurance in tibialis posterior muscle  –Initially may show a normal single-leg  calf raise and decreased endurance, with inability to perform successive single-leg calf raises

As dysfunction progresses, may see: –Hindfoot valgus and/or forefoot abducted and supinated: initially flexible but can become rigid –MLA collapse (flatfoot deformity): initially may return when non-weight-bearing  but can progress to a more permanent deformity

Classification of posterior tibialtendon dysfunction(9,10,11) –Stage I -Tendon is intact but inflamed -Normal tendon length –Stage II -Tendon no longer functional -Tendon is elongated and more permanent changes have occurred -Loss of MLA and presence of acquired flatfoot -May be corrected by passive means – foot retains flexibility –Stage III -Deformity is rigid -Degenerative changes are present (in subtalar joint) –Stage IV -Degenerative changes are seen in the ankle Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

causes: The precise etiology is unknown; however, theories include the following:(1)–Inadequate blood supply to the area–Abnormal foot mechanics (e.g., exaggerated antagonist contractions by the peroneus brevis)
pathogenesis: The mechanisms of any tendinopathy are complex. They often involve mechanical stress, degenerative changes in thetendon tissue, and disorganized healing(14)
Fibrosis occurs in the PTT due to recurrent microtrauma(1)

Most agree posterior tibialis tendinopathy is a progressive disorder. Soft tissue tendinopathy in the posterior tibialis leadsto altered foot biomechanics. Progressive loss of the MLA leads to acquired flatfoot deformity.This results in secondaryreactive changes including subsequent ligament(superomedial calcaneonavicular ligament) and tendon attenuation.Halluxvalgus may occur due to transversely shifted weight-bearing  along with secondary osteoarthritis due to instability(8,11)

In a study from the United Kingdom comparing normal PTTs, stage II dysfunctional tendons, and replacement tendonsafter surgical transfer, tissue samples were analyzed for total collagen, glycosaminoglycan, pentosidine, and collagencrosslinks(3)–Stage II dysfunctional PTTs showed biochemical and molecular changes consistent with chronic remodeling of theextracellular matrix, rather than rupture–This remodeling process may be indicative of an incomplete healing response to repeated microtrauma or overuse
risk factors: Sex: more common in females–Estrogen receptor gene variants have been found to be associated with posterior tibialistendinopathy(14)

Accessory navicular bone in the foot–Having an accessory navicular bone can cause various foot problems, including posterior tibialis tendon pathology, lossof the MLA, and foot pain. Researchers found that having an accessory navicular bone is substantially influenced bygenetics(16)

overall contraindications precautions: Refer the patient back to the physician if symptoms do not improve with conservative management
See specific  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan of Care

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Patients typically present after weeks of aching and tenderness near the medial malleolus as well as pain extending into the arch of the foot. Most patients have not experienced direct calf or ankle trauma

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management Conservative management is attempted initially(11) A period of immobilization and rest may be tried in the early stages(11) In recalcitrant cases or in cases associated with inflammatory arthropathies, surgery may be considered(11)minimally invasive techniques for tendon synovectomytendon transfer using either the flexor hallucis longus or the flexor digitorum longus.A calcaneal osteotomy is usually performed as well to prevent premature reelongation  or re-rupture  of the reconstructed posterior tibialistriple arthrodesis. In the future, ankle arthroplasty may be a good option as techniques and prostheses improve
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? Are they effective? NSAIDS to alleviate pain. The use of corticosteroids is controversial because of the increased risk for tendon rupture. Plateletrich plasma injections may be beneficial, but evidence is lacking(11) Diagnostic tests completed  (11) The diagnosis usually is based on clinical examination. However, special clinical tests have only modest accuracy in identifying pathology. Xrays  may be needed to rule out fracture. If flatfoot deformity is present, weight-bearing images can help to quantify the degree of deformity Ultrasound (US) is helpful in evaluating the PTT MRI is important for the assessment of tendon or ligament rupture Foot pressure analysis for objective assessment of foot arches
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Ask patient to describe the main aggravating activity. The pain generally is worse after walking. Pain usually improves with rest
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night related to the condition
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., marked increase in swelling) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes___ No___ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Is there a history of ankle injuries or prior ankle pain?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in recreational or competitive sports?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Does the patient wear orthotics; if so, how old are the orthotics? Does the patient report any limitations in ADLs?
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting.) Complete a general exam as indicated with a focus on the items listed below
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Is the patient currently using foot orthotics? Are they appropriate?
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess static and dynamic balance reactions in stance
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Distal pulses should be normalDoes the patient report any paresthesias? Complete a dermatome scan to assist in ruling out nerve impairmentComplete a functional assessment as indicted
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess the patient’s gait; note deviations –Authors of a systematic review and meta-analysis  compared foot/ankle kinematics and kinetics in patients with posterior tibial tendon dysfunction with healthy controls during gait(10) -Results showedthat patients with posterior tibial tendon dysfunction had increased dorsiflexion and abduction in the forefoot and increased plantarflexion and eversion in the hindfoot during the stance phase of walking -These kinematics during the stance phase of walking may be associated with the pathological process of posterior tibial tendon dysfunctionAssess the integrity of the joints within the foot; document any hyper-  or hypomobility –Authors of a study (N = 32) compared first ray mobility of patients with flatfeet with and without symptoms of posterior tibial tendon dysfunction.First ray mobility did not differ between symptomatic patients and asymptomatic controls. First ray mobility was not associated with posterior tibial tendon dysfunction(12)Is there any atypical muscle tone noted?
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Manual muscle testing to assess strength of the muscles of the lower leg. Compare results to unaffected ankle. Assess strength of knee and hip stabilizers, which may contribute to faulty mechanics with squatting/running/stairs, etc.
observation inspection palpation includi: Assess tenderness (V AS) to palpation posterior to the medial malleolus and along the instep at the navicular. Palpate for increased prominence of the navicular on the plantar surface of the foot
Assess for provocation of pain with plantar flexion and inversion against resistance

Mild swelling may be noted in the ankle joint or posterior to the medial malleolus. Circumferential measurements should be completed proximal and distal to the malleoli and a figure 8 measurement about the entire joint should be taken. Compare with the unaffected side
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess general posture and the ankles and knees for symmetry. Inspect for alignment faults at the ankle, including dropping of the inside of the ankle, flattening of the foot arch, and bowing of the Achilles tendon and the heel inward.(1) These occur with an over-elongated  tibialis posterior. The toes point outwards, such that when the kneecap is pointing forward the foot is rotated laterally with reference to the knee. Knee alignment faults are associated with a knock-kneed stance, in which the femur rotates medially and adducts, causing the kneecap of the affected leg to face inward. Compare to the contralateral limb
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Determine active and passive ROM of the foot/ankle. Goniometric measurements should be completed for dorsiflexion, plantar flexion, inversion, and eversion. Compare to the contralateral limb
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Complete a reflex assessment as indicatedAssess ability to complete ADLs as indicated
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Functional leg length(4) -With the patient standing, the clinician feels the anterior superior iliac spines (ASISs) as well as the posterior superior iliac spines (PSISs) and assesses for asymmetry -The clinician adjusts the patient’s feet to position the patient in subtalar neutral; this position is then held -The ASISs and PSISs are felt once again; if asymmetries persist, the pelvis requires further examination -If asymmetries are corrected, an ankle/foot impairment is likely causing a functional leg-length discrepancy (may also be from hip or knee) -Leg-length  discrepancy may be associated with posterior tibial tendon dysfunction. Changes in gait on both the shorter limb and the longer limb can place increased stress on the PTT(10)With the patient in normal standing position, an assessment of the feet from behind will show more visible toes on the outside of the affected leg compared to the unaffected leg. This is due to the fallen arch (i.e., hyperpronation) and malalignment of the foot(1,2)The patient attempts to complete 10 single-leg  heel raises without support. Positive test occurs with reproduction of pain or inability to complete full motion with each heel raise, or the inability to complete the specified number of heel raises when compared to the other side(11) –Feiss line(4) -With the patient in sitting (no weight on feet), the clinician draws a small point on the apex of the medial malleolus and plantar region of the first metatarsophalangeal joint; a line is then drawn connecting these two points -The clinician feels the navicular tuberosity and marks its position in relation to the line intersecting the points marked in the first step -With the patient instance, the position of the navicular tuberosity is noted again; typically (in the normal foot) the tuberosity will fall on/near the line -First-degree  flatfoot – navicular tuberosity lowers one third of distance to the floor -Second-degree  flatfoot – navicular tuberosity lowers two thirds of distance to the floor -Third-degree  flatfoot – navicular tuberosity touches the floor –Patla tibialis posterior length test(4) -While the patient is prone with the knee on the involved side flexed to 90°, the examiner dorsiflexes and everts the ankle with one hand -The thumb of the examiner’s other hand is then placed over the plantar surface of the bases of the second, third, and fourth metatarsals and the index and middle fingers over the plantar surface of the navicular -The metatarsals and the navicular are then pushed dorsally, and the end feel is compared to the contralateral foot -A positive test is the reproduction of the patient’s symptoms, which is indicative of a dysfunctional PTT

other: Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary listed below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols. Only those  contraindications/precautions that apply to this diagnosis are mentioned below. Rehabilitation professionals should use their own professional judgment when treating patients

Patients with this diagnosis may be at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Exertional pain in the posterior tibial tendon with restricted strength, in conjunction with foot, ankle, or knee alignment faults. Trial of physical therapy to reduce pain, improve ankle/foot and knee alignment, and restore function(2)
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Ankle sprain Fracture (tibial, fibular, calcaneal) Achilles tendon pathology Osteoarthritis(1) Collapsed arch secondary to aging or obesity(1) Shin splints or stress fractures of the lower leg Plantar fasciitis Calcaneal bone spurs Posterior tibial nerve entrapment Anterior or posterior compartment syndrome DVT Lisfranc dislocation(2) Generalized dysplasia (ligamentous laxity)(2) Idiopathic pes planus(2) Congenital pes planus(2)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Orthopedist or podiatrist as indicated Orthotist
other considerations: Authors of a radiographic study evaluated the prevalence of bony impingement using weight-bearing  CT scans of patients with flatfeet with posterior tibial tendon dysfunction. They found that 35% of patients had bony impingement between the fibula and calcaneus. Thirty-eight  percent had bony impingement between the talus and calcaneus. Accurate diagnosis of bony impingement is necessary for surgical decision-making(13)
treatment summary: Conservative treatment is indicated for nearly all patients.(1) Pain management, strengthening, and stretching are the main physical therapy interventions recommended. Fitting for orthotics may also be warranted. Patients with posterior tibial tendinopathy benefit from a program of progressive strengthening. The physical therapy treatment plan should also involve patient education on the risk of faulty techniques and sports training errors, as well as discussion of acceptable approaches to relative rest and activity modification. A realistic period for return to sports is 3–4 weeks after resolution of pain in aggravating activities
Treatment approach will vary depending on stage of posterior tibial tendon dysfunction; please see classification system in Presentation/signs and symptoms , above(1)

Increased activation of intrinsic foot muscles is important in supporting the MLA. Short-foot  exercises (SFE)focus on isolating the intrinsic muscles. Authors of a study (N = 15) investigated the effects of a 4-week  SFE intervention on biomechanical factors in patients with stage II posterior tibial tendon dysfunction(9) –SFE intervention consisted of patients performing activation of the intrinsic foot muscles 15 repetitions, 5 times/day, 3 times/per for 4 weeks. Patients were instructed to pull their first metatarsal head toward the calcaneus without toe flexion or extension (causing activation of extrinsic muscles) along with the elevation ofMLA and shortening oftheir involved foot in an anterior-posterior  direction. They were also asked to place the forefoot and heel on the ground during holding (isometric contraction) time. During the first week, neuromuscular electrostimulation was used to assist in activation of the intrinsic muscles  –Although the exercise program failed at changing the structural deformity (increase MLA height), it did have positive effects on changing the activation patterns for the tibialis anterior muscle and the fibularis longus muscle. These often present with an abnormal compensatory muscle activation in patients with posterior tibialtendon dysfunction –Clinicians should consider using both SFE and extrinsic muscle strengthening over a longer training period to produce more beneficial results

Calcaneal-cuboid  manipulation was found to immediately reduce symptoms and increase function in a patient with posterior tibialis tendinopathy in a 2015 case report(7) –Initial treatment (prior to the manipulation) consisted of stretching, soft tissue mobilization, therapeutic exercise, and taping –After minimal gains were made, manipulation was performed with patient prone while therapist used an internal rotation directed high velocity, low amplitude thrust at the calcaneal-cuboid  joint –Immediately after manipulation, patient reported 0/10 pain. With 6 weeks of additional treatment, the patient was able to return to pain-free  running –A posterior tibialis lengthening exercise was added to the patient’s home program after manipulation. While standing, the patient maintained knee extension and lower leg internal rotation to create pronation of the rear and midfoot, which in turn lengthened the posterior tibialis

In patients with posterior tibialis tendinopathy, orthoses and therapeutic exercise may improve function of the involved foot(6) –Based on an RCT with 36 participants –Participants with stage I or II disease were randomized to one of the following (for 12 weeks) -Orthoses and stretching -Orthoses, stretching, and concentric progressive resistive exercise -Orthoses, stretching, and eccentric progressive resistive exercise –Outcome measures included the Foot Function Index, 5-minute walk test, and recorded pain after the 5-minute  walk test –Pain was significantly reduced in all intervention groups –Foot Function Index scores improved in all intervention groups –No comparisons between groups were reported due to significant differences in scores between groups at baseline . improved balance: Berg Balance Scale or other balance assessment tool

maintenance or prevention: Similar to athletes recovering from stress fractures, patients treated for PTT pain should be given an independent ankle strengthening/stretching program and advised to correct poor ankle alignment. Orthotics should be worn during athletic participation, if warranted
